opener.dateline: London - 24 Sussex place Regents park June the 4th 1829

div.p:
We
heard with great pain of
the domestic affliction with
which you were lately visited
: it interrupted our prospects
of seeing Mr & Mrs Wilson
- but I am happy to say
we are at length indulged
with the promise of their
company to dinner next
Saturday. Then we are

off - Sophia & the children
immediately & I as soon as
possible afterwards - for
Tweedside, till winter. Is there
any chance of your being
in Scotland this season? It
is to be hoped Mrs Wilson will
draw you to London perforce
against the spring however

And now for petitions &
first as concerns others. The
XmasChristmas box this last year wdwould have
died entirely but for the Snow
woman - & even wwith that redeeming

piece, the general dulnessdullness &
silliness have so depressed the
sale that the work has been
abandoned by the proprietor
& is now taken up by John
Murray, who is moving
heaven & Earth to do it
more justice - I promised I
wdwould write to you. He has set
his heart on another Garry
Owen tale - But in short
any little piece of yours wdwould
be highly valued &, (in
case I may speak boldly)
properly considered and I

shall be much obliged by
an answer. I have written
also to Miss Baillie & have
her promise.

Now for selfish concerns.
I have ventured to be a
proprietor of a new work
entitled The Family Library
of which you may have seen
the advertisements at least.
A third of it is mine - & you
will perceive by the lists that
I have procured good names
at least for support; &

as We have begun with a
sale so considerable (already
near 7000) that there is a
fair chance of the specul-
-ationspeculation turning out well
as concerns the shareholders
& I think there is every
chance of the work being
the means of doing good.
It wdwould give it wings to
have a volume for you
& if you cdcould fancy any
subject, historical, biographical

or scientific, I am sure
every effort to meet your
wishes in all respects
might be relied on. I
thought you might perhaps
like to write a few female
lives and no doubt such
a vol.volume or volumes from
your pen wdwould be charming.

postscript.p:
May I beg best remembrances to
Mrs Edgeworth -

I have a letter today fmfrom
Sir Walter. He is in capital
spirits, - his new edition of the
Novels succeeding beyond all
expectation - high as that
must have been.
